Title: Association between maternal exposure to perfluoroalkyl and polyfluoroalkyl substances and risks of adverse pregnancy outcomes: A systematic review and meta-analysis
Authors: Zhuoma Deji, Peng Liu, Xin Wang, Xin Zhang, Yuehua Luo, Zhenzhen Huang
Reasoning for "PFAS one many":
The paper focuses on multiple types of PFAS substances in its evidence synthesis and meta-analysis. This is evident from the following quotes:
Perfluoroalkyl and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFASs) and their derivatives are a class of persistent organic pollutants containing a hydrophobic chain fully or partially saturated with fluorine atoms.
There are sixteen, sixteen, eight and eight studies that assessed the relationship between maternal PFOA, PFOS, PFNA and PFHxS exposure and preterm birth, respectively.
The combined results suggested a positive relationship between maternal exposure to PFOS and the risk of preterm birth.
No associations were found between maternal PFOA (pooled OR = 0.98, 95% CI: 0.89, 1.08; I 2 = 54.6%, p = 0.005) (Fig. 5B ), PFNA (pooled OR = 1.03, 95% CI: 0.89, 1.18; I 2 = 36.3%, p = 0.139) (Fig. 5C ), PFHxS (pooled OR = 0.96, 95% CI: 0.85, 1.09; I 2 = 20.9%, p = 0.263) (Fig. 5D ) concentrations and preterm birth.

Title: ENVIRONMENTAL CONTAMINANT EXPOSURES AND PRETERM BIRTH: A COMPREHENSIVE REVIEW
Authors: Kelly K Ferguson, Marie S O'neill, John D Meeker
Venue: Journal of Toxicology and Environmental Health. Part B, Critical Reviews
Reasoning for "PFAS one many":
The review focuses on two main types of PFAS chemicals in terms of evidence synthesis: perfluorooctanoic acid (PFOA) and perfluorooctane sulfonic acid (PFOS). This is evident from the following quotes:
Perfluorinated chemicals repel oil, grease, and water and are used to treat carpets and clothing to prevent stains, and are also components of some food containers and wrappers (ATSDR, 2009) . Through product use and manufacturing they can be released into the environment, and do not degrade in soil or water. Exposure occurs through consumption of contaminated drinking water and food, inadvertent ingestion of indoor dust, and potentially through inhalation (ATSDR, 2009) . The two compounds produced in largest quantities include perfluorooctanoic acid (PFOA) and perfluorooctane sulfonic acid (PFOS).
Several recent studies examined the relationship between PFOA and PFOS exposure and preterm birth.
Four studies examined associations in populations where exposure levels were relatively low and on the same order of magnitude as those observed in the general U.S. population. Apelberg et al. (2007) measured PFOA and PFOS levels in cord serum from newborns in the Baltimore THREE study, where a relatively high proportion of births were preterm (n = 293, preterm = 28). No significant differences in median concentrations were detected, however, in term compared to preterm samples.
